subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal, yet again.
msgSnippet: ... For Unicode purposes, the issue is not how many variants there are, but how many *free* variants there are, that is, those which are (a) unpredictable and
messageBody:
othermale scripsit:

> That is excellent news and this maybe beside the point but I did
> just want to point out that there are more variations to characters
> than those listed in the proposal and that some characters have more
> than one variation.

For Unicode purposes, the issue is not how many variants there are,
but how many *free* variants there are, that is, those which are
(a) unpredictable and (b) make a difference. A Latin script font
needs at least three glyphs for "i" (initial, medial, final) but
only one character, because which one to use is predictable from the
surrounding characters. On the other hand, it needs a separate "&"
character even though that was originally a ligature for "et", because
the font renderer cannot predict when to use "et" and when to use "&".
and they have completely different meanings.

--
Overhead, without any fuss, the stars were going out.
--Arthur C. Clarke, "The Nine Billion Names of God"
John Cowan <cowan@...>

> just want to point out that there are more variations to characters
> than those listed in the proposal and that some characters have more
> than one variation.
